BlogHomeThursday seminar spring 2022

Dijkgraaf-Witten theory

Jun 1, 2019

Summer’s begun (finally!). I want to try to explain some concepts in topological QFT which I’ve been reading about. This past semester, I took MIT’s 8.06 (quantum physics III), for which we had to write a final paper on a topic of our choosing. I wrote about anyons, which are particles with fractional statistics — they only exist in two spatial dimensions, thanks to the nontriviality of the fundamental group of the configuration space of points in the plane (equivalently, thanks to the triviality of the angular momentum commutation relations in two dimensions). In my writeup, I discussed how one can construct anyonic particles from a conserved charged matter current and a gauge field by adding a Chern-Simons term to the Lagrangian; the Euler-Lagrange equation which this additional term contributes to forces the magnetic field (associated to the gauge field) and the charge to be related, and the Aharonov-Bohm effect then forces the resulting physics to be that of an anyon.

The term that’s added to the Lagrangian is the “Chern-Simons term”

where is the conserved current and is the gauge field. The pure Chern-Simons action is

where is the background -dimensional (closed, oriented) manifold. This action is special: it does not depend on the metric at all — the Chern-Simons theory is purely topological. The associated quantum field theory, with path integral/partition function only depends on the topology of the manifold. As such, Chern-Simons theory should be accessible through topology.

The Chern-Simons Lagrangian can be rephrased more mathematically as follows. Let , and let be a connection on the trivial -bundle over the -dimensional spacetime (all we need right now is that be closed and oriented), so . The Lagrangian is then ; this is a -form on . The action is the integral of this -form; if we think of this -form as a singular cochain, then the integral is just the evaluation of this cochain (or rather, its image in cohomology) on the fundamental class of (recall, we assumed oriented).

Setting it up in this level of generality provides us a path to follow. Let’s (obviously) work with general -dimensional closed oriented manifolds. Replace with a finite group (then the Lie algebra is trivial, but that’s OK). Instead of the Chern-Simons Lagrangian, we’d like to have a top-dimensional cohomology class defined on all closed connected -manifolds (“spacetimes”), so that the action is the pairing of this class with the fundamental class. The natural choice for this class is a choice of cohomology class ; every -bundle with connection on determines an element of , hence (by integration). This should be thought of as the exponentiated action of the field .

In order to define the path integral, we need to define a measure on the collection of -bundles on . As is ubiquitous in math, we weight the term associated to by . Concretely, the exponentiated action is , and the associated path integral is

This is the -model known as Dijkgraaf-Witten theory; it’s a prototype for the general Chern-Simons theory. It’s a rather accessible topological quantum field theory. In an -dimensional TQFT, one assigns a number to a closed oriented -manifold, a complex vector space to a closed oriented -manifold, and a linear transformation to a cobordism between -manifolds; what is the associated vector space in the case of Dijkgraaf-Witten theory?

Let be an oriented -manifold. There is a map , which defines a class in . We can push this cohomology class along the projection map ; this defines an element of , and hence an element of . Associated to this class is a line bundle over , and is defined to be the -vector space of global sections of .

If and are closed oriented -manifolds, and is an oriented bordism from to , we need an associated linear transformation . There are maps , so we get a map — however, there is no obvious map

We are saved, though: there are canonical isomorphisms

The covariant functoriality of homology now does the trick.

At some point, it was realized that extending -dimensional TQFTs to prescribe algebraic invariants to manifolds of lower dimensions (, etc.) was a mathematically useful thing to do. An extended -dimensional TQFT is then defined as a symmetric monoidal functor , where is the -category of oriented points, oriented bordisms of oriented points, oriented bordisms between these -morphisms, etc., and is a symmetric monoidal -category. The utility of this definition comes from the cobordism hypothesis: extended -dimensional TQFTs with values in are the same as fully dualizable objects of .

In the case of -dimensional Chern-Simons theory, we described above what one might attach to an -manifold (the -morphisms in ) and a -manifold (the -morphisms in ). What does one attach to manifolds of lower dimensions? Let’s specialize to the case when . In this case, we’re asking what one might assign to (oriented) points. To begin with, we need to make a choice of : it will be the -category of algebras, bimodules, and morphisms of bimodules. The classification of (extended) -dimensional TQFTs via the cobordism hypothesis says that an extended -dimensional TQFT is determined by a Frobenius algebra (i.e., a finite-dimensional -algebra equipped with a nondegenerate trace). Therefore, -dimensional Dijkgraaf-Witten theory must be determined by such a Frobenius algebra. Choose a cocycle representative, also denoted , for our cohomology class — note that this isn’t a crazy thing to ask for, since the -dimensional Chern-Simons action explicitly used a -form, and not just a -cocycle — and let be the twisted group ring . The underlying complex vector space is the same as the usual group ring , but the multiplication is twisted by :

This twisted group algebra has a canonical trace, and hence admits the structure of a Frobenius algebra; the associated -dimensional TQFT is Dijkgraaf-Witten theory. Of course, one can run the same story for extended -dimensional Dijkgraaf-Witten theory; for an appropriate choice of target -category, one finds that the associated extended -dimensional TQFT is determined by a twisted group algebra with coefficients in the category of complex vector spaces.

Let’s go back to our definition of the partition function on a closed oriented -manifold . Associated to a principal -bundle on was the classical (exponentiated) action, defined as the integral of the characteristic class . The quantization of this theory was defined as a weighted sum over isomorphism classes of principal -bundles of this action. Consider the (for simplicity, -)category of closed oriented -manifolds with a -bundle and compact oriented -manifolds with a -bundle; then the classical action defines a symmetric monoidal functor , sending an -manifold and a principal -bundle to the -vector space given by the fiber of the bundle over . The quantization of this classical theory can be thought of as a sort of right Kan extension of the functor along the forgetful functor (where the target is now the -category obtained by truncating the -category of bordisms).

We can adopt a slightly different viewpoint of this quantization procedure in the following manner: rather than assigning a number (the action) to each field (principal -bundle) on a manifold (spacetime), we can assign to each spacetime the space of all fields, and sum the action over this space with respect to a particular measure. A little more precisely, let be an -dimensional spacetime, and let be the space of fields on (in the Dijkgraaf-Witten story, this was ). Let and be spacelike slices of , so is an oriented bordism between and . There are spaces (groupoids, really) and of fields on and , but on which there is no classical action; there are also maps . We may view as defining a functor from to the category of correspondences of groupoids. In the Dijkgraaf-Witten theory, had more structure: it was equipped with a local system of complex vector spaces (such that the global sections of was the space of states on ), i.e., a functor .

A natural generalization, therefore, is to generalize the (-, really) category of correspondences of groupoids to the -category of groupoids equipped a functor to the target -category — or, more generally, some data of “-local systems on ”. A classical theory is a symmetric monoidal functor . What, then, is the quantization of this theory? It is an extension of the functor to a functor , via the functor sending a groupoid and a functor to the limit (so must admit limits; let’s also assume that it admits colimits). It’s not clear that this assignment even defines a functor , for the same reason as in the Dijkgraaf-Witten situation: the limit is the cohomology of over , but cohomology is contravariant. In this Dijkgraaf-Witten case, this was resolved by noting that there was an isomorphism between homology and cohomology — we need a similar coincidence to take place in . (See this paper for a proof that the construction sketched out above in fact agrees with Dijkgraaf-Witten theory.)

More precisely, suppose that is a bordism between and ; then, there is a map . Let be the map induced from the bordism; what we are seeking is a map . Suppose that the map is -ambidextrous; what this means is that the left and right Kan extensions (respectively) are equivalent via the norm map. If is the terminal map, then (resp. ) is the global sections (i.e., “take the limit”) functor on (resp. ). In particular, the map we’d want would be automatic from the existence of a map of -valued local systems on . By -ambidexterity,

we therefore obtain a canonical map , since is left adjoint to . In order to obtain an interesting TQFT, we should therefore: choose a nice symmetric monoidal -category admitting limits by groupoids, and define a classical theory such that bordisms induce -ambidextrous morphisms of groupoids. Phrased another way to place emphasis more on the category than on the morphisms, one would like a functor/classical theory and an -category for which every morphism of -finite groupoids is -ambidextrous. (If we’re generalizing anyway, I don’t see why we should restrict to the category of groupoids and -local systems on them; perhaps physical considerations suggest looking at a category of -categories for and -local systems on them, i.e., assigning to a manifold an -category of “fields”.)

This is where the ambidexterity results of Hopkins and Lurie comes into play. Let denote the -category of -local spectra. Then Hopkins-Lurie prove that every map of -finite spaces (i.e., spaces with finitely many homotopy groups, each of which are finite) is -ambidextrous. It follows that if is a classical theory taking values in -finite spaces/groupoids, then there is an associated TQFT taking values in . We can either view this as a (boring) -dimensional TQFT, or as a non-extended -dimensional TQFT for any . Note that this TQFT is determined by a fully dualizable (i.e., dualizable) object in , aka a spectrum whose -homology is finite-dimensional over .

One can further generalize this story: let be an -ring, and let be an oriented -divisible group over (for a fixed prime ). Let be the -category of -modules. For every space , one can associate an -category of -tempered local systems (these should be thought of as “twisted” local systems of -modules on ). Lurie proves in Elliptic III that if is a map of -finite spaces (i.e., -finite with all homotopy groups assumed to be finite abelian -groups), then the functors are equivalent via the norm map. In other words, if is a classical theory taking values in -finite spaces/groupoids, where is the ordinary -category of cobordisms, then there is an associated TQFT taking values in . As before, this TQFT is determined by a fully dualizable (i.e., dualizable) object in .

How can we construct a functor ? One way to do so is to generalize the Dijkgraaf-Witten story. Namely, choose a -finite space , and send to the -finite space . Of course, we need to define a functor for every -manifold . In order to do this, we run a construction similar to the classical (untwisted) situation: simply choose an -module , and let the local system over be the constant one.

If we choose , then the value of the resulting TQFT on a closed -manifold (i.e., the partition function of ) is

This is alternatively the homotopy cardinality of .

It’d be very interesting to find -categories for which similar ambidexterity results hold, consequently generalizing Dijkgraaf-Witten theory. I’d also like to know whether physical considerations lead to conjectural target -categories.
